chapter.title: Reading Activity
chapter.content:
The development of expertise—a firm conceptual understanding that can be applied to a variety of tasks and situations—may take thousands of hours of practice. Given the competing demands of adults’ lives and the often limited access to educational services, how can adult educators provide instruction in a way that maximizes the learning potential of every available hour?

The National Research Council's report titled Improving Adult Literacy Instruction: Supporting Learning and Motivation describes a set of 14 evidence-based principles that can guide the design of effective instruction for adults. The Highlights of Key Principles of Learning for Instructional Design page lists these principles, with brief descriptions excerpted from Improving Adult Literacy Instruction: Supporting Learning and Motivation. **

**Extended Learning Opportunity: Optional Reading
Note: To view the principles and explanations as a whole rather than as separate excerpts in the Highlights document, read Chapter 2 (pp. 3–11) from Improving Adult Literacy Instruction: Supporting Learning and Motivation.

Access this chapter by downloading the 32-page booklet as a PDF from Improving Adult Literacy Instruction: Supporting Learning and Motivation. Reprinted with permission from the National Academy of Sciences, Courtesy of the National Academies Press, Washington, DC.

chapter.title: Pre-Viewing Activity
chapter.content:
The video clip you will watch is of Andrea Echelberger’s low-level English as a Second Language (ESL) class of emergent readers. Answer the following questions in your optional course journal or other note-taking location. You can read more about each of the Descriptions of 14 Principles, if needed.

  1. Which of the 14 principles do you think are most important to see demonstrated in a class of beginning English learners? Choose three from the following list of principles.

  2. Which of the 14 principles might be challenging to address in a low-level ESL class? Choose three from the following list of principles.

 

14 Principles of Learning for Instructional Design

Help learners acquire, retain, and transfer new knowledge and skills

  • Choose appropriate level of difficulty.

  • Present material in a clear and organized format.

  • Use multiple and varied examples and formats.

  • Space presentations of new material across time.

  • Test on multiple occasions preferably with spacing.

  • Ground concepts in concrete experiences.

Support learners in generating content and reasoning

  • Encourage learners to generate content.

  • Encourage learners to generate explanations and resolve contradictions.

  • Encourage learners to construct ideas from multiple points of view and different perspectives.

Develop meta-cognition and self-directed learning

  • Structure instruction to develop effective use of complex learning strategies.

  • Combine instruction in complex learning strategies with learning of content.

Provide feedback

  • Promote learning by offering accurate and timely feedback

  • Promote learning by giving qualitative feedback rather than test scores and flagging errors

Use adaptive, interactive learning environments

  • Provide opportunities to practice and use skills for a purpose.

chapter.title: Listening Task
chapter.content:
The course PowerPoint presentations and sample video provide many concrete examples of what the key principles look like in daily classroom practice.

As you watch and listen, note new teaching strategies you learn about and add them to your Instructional Design Strategies Chart (Word) that you downloaded and filled out in the pre-course self-assessment. Especially consider jotting down any strategies that relate to the principles where you gave yourself a score of 1 or 2.

chapter.title: PPT 1: Principles of Learning for Instructional Design, Part 1
chapter.content:
This PowerPoint presentation features two subject matter experts, Rob Jenkins and Maricel Santos, discussing how to implement these principles of learning for instructional design in the classroom.

  • Rob Jenkins is Associate Professor of English as a Second Language at Santa Ana College School of Continuing Education.

  • Maricel Santos is Associate Professor of English at San Francisco State University.

  • The presenters draw several examples from ESL contexts, and these may easily be adapted for use in ABE/ASE classes.

  • The presenters share examples through teaching/learning vignettes. As you listen, consider the principles of learning you read about in Unit 1 and which form the basis of the Pre-Course self-assessment you took. Rob and Maricel will recap these principles in Part 2 of the PowerPoint Presentation.

  • TIP: To hear Rob and Maricel’s narration, be sure to view this PowerPoint presentation in Slideshow mode and turn up the volume on your speakers or headset. You will control the speed of the presentation by pressing “enter” on your keyboard when you are ready to move ahead.

chapter.title: Video: Building Literacy with Adult Emergent Readers
chapter.content:
Now is a good time to get comfortable in your seat, turn on your speakers, and get ready to watch an engaging video of Andrea’s class. Watch the first few segments, through time marker 16 minutes, 45 seconds. (You will have an opportunity to watch the entire video in Unit 2.)

In this lesson, you will see Andrea teach various literacy skills to a beginning level group of learners.

  • As you watch, think about the following: How does Andrea help the learners acquire, retain, and apply new literacy skills?

  • Think about how you might do this in your own classroom.

chapter.content:
Every classroom context has its own challenges and opportunities for implementing the principles of learning.

  • Thinking about the ESL lesson example you observed in the video, which principles do you think were best demonstrated? You can review the Descriptions of 14 Principles1 if needed. Use your optional course journal or other note-taking location to specify which 3 of the 14 principles you think were best demonstrated.   • What moments in the videotaped class do you think demonstrate effective instruction? (Use the Principles of learning for Instructional Design course thread in LINCS Evidence-Based Professional Development Community of Practice, to share your ideas with other practitioners and also see what other participants from this course have noted).

14 Principles of Learning for Instructional Design:

Help learners acquire, retain, and transfer new knowledge and skills

  • Choose appropriate level of difficulty.

  • Present material in a clear and organized format.

  • Use multiple and varied examples and formats.

  • Space presentations of new material across time.

  • Test on multiple occasions preferably with spacing.

  • Ground concepts in concrete experiences.

Support learners in generating content and reasoning

  • Encourage learners to generate content.

  • Encourage learners to generate explanations and resolve contradictions.

  • Encourage learners to construct ideas from multiple points of view and different perspectives.

Develop meta-cognition and self-directed learning

  • Structure instruction to develop effective use of complex learning strategies.

  • Combine instruction in complex learning strategies with learning of content.

Provide feedback

  • Promote learning by offering accurate and timely feedback

  • Promote learning by giving qualitative feedback rather than test scores and flagging errors

Use adaptive, interactive learning environments

  • Learning is enhanced by opportunities to practice and use skills for a purpose.

 

1 Descriptions of each principle are taken from Chapter 2 (pp. 3–11) from Improving Adult Literacy: Supporting Learning and Motivation. They are reprinted with permission from the National Academy of Sciences, Courtesy of the National Academies Press, Washington, DC.

chapter.title: Supporting Learning in an Adult Basic Education (ABE) Context
chapter.content:
As you’ve already seen, the teaching context (ESL/ABE, skill level, class size, and so forth) is bound to affect the way the instructional principles are addressed in the classroom. For example, as Rob and Maricel described how to apply these principles in ESL classes, they spoke extensively about building on student strengths and interests, being transparent with students about the organization and purpose of activities, and effective ways of providing feedback to students. They spoke less about strategies that may be difficult to implement when students have limited English, such as those related to “developing metacognition and self-directed learning.”

Here are five teaching strategies that help ABE students better understand and direct their own learning.

  1. Model learning tasks for students by “thinking aloud” as you do them.

  2. Teach students the vocabulary to talk about learning: strategy, concept, feedback, and so forth.

  3. Scaffold instruction with graphic organizers, structured prompts, and so forth that help students carry out learning activities.

  4. Invite students to reflect on their learning (at the end of a lesson, for example).

  5. Use how and why questions to help students articulate what they understand and to draw their attention to how they know.
